member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.DefaultTabStyle
member.summary: Style object used to paint a tab when it is in a normal state (enabled, not selected and has no mouse).

remarks.p: The property of a particular tab has priority over that property.

This property is merged with the this.ControlStyle. It means that if the BackColor, ForeColor, Font, or sub-properties related to the border are not set, then values of corresponding properties of the this.ControlStyle are used.
When this property is set, then the reference to the original Style object remains the same, and Style-subproperties are copied using the Style.CopyFrom(...) method.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.HoverTabStyle
member.summary: Style object used to paint a tab when the mouse is over it .

remarks.p: The property of a particular tab has priority over that property.
This property is merged with the property.
When this property is set, then the reference to the original Style object remains the same, and Style-subproperties are copied using the Style.CopyFrom(...) method.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.SelectedTabStyle
member.summary: Style object used to paint a tab when it is selected.

remarks.p: The property of a particular tab has priority over that property.
This property is merged with the property.
When this property is set, then the reference to the original Style object remains the same, and Style-subproperties are copied using the Style.CopyFrom(...) method.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.DisabledTabStyle
member.summary: Style object used to paint a tab when it is disabled.

remarks.p: The property of a particular tab has priority over that property.
This property is merged with the property.
When this property is set, then the reference to the original Style object remains the same, and Style-subproperties are copied using the Style.CopyFrom(...) method.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.DefaultTabSeparatorStyle
member.summary: Style object used to paint tab separators.

remarks.p: The property of a particular separator has priority over that property.
When this property is set, then the reference to the original Style object remains the same, and Style-subproperties are copied using the Style.CopyFrom(...) method.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.Tabs
member.summary: Reference to the collection.

remarks.p: This property can be used to retrieve any object in the collection.
The object returned can be of type or . Each language in .Net has its own method of determining the type of an object, for example, the keyword is can be used in C#.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.ClientSideEvents
member.summary: The ClientSideEvents object maintains the names of JavaScript functions that are to be called on the client side in response to various events that can be processed there without the need for a server post-back.

remarks.p: Every member property can contain the name of an implemented function or explicit javascript statement(s). If the name of a function (only name: no parenthesis or parameters) is used, then actual implementation on the client may contain parameters: please see documentation for Client-Side Object Model.

When this property is set, then the reference to the original ClientSideEvents object remains the same, and ClientSideEvents-subproperties are copied using the "ClientSideEvents.CopyFrom(...)" method.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.RoundedImage
member.summary: The RoundedImage object maintains properties related to the rounded shape of tabs.

ul.li: To enable rounded images, the should be set to a value other than None.
To customize images the image related properties should be set, such as the

To customize images it is also possible to modify default images that are located at the
C:\Inetpub\wwwroot\aspnet_client\Infragistics\WebBars2\Images
Names of default images for a particular configuration of TabOrientation and TextOrientation appear within the property.
When this property is set, then the reference to the original RoundedImage object remains the same, and RoundedImage-subproperties are copied using the "RoundedImage.CopyFrom(...)" method.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.BorderDetails
member.summary: Returns or sets colors, widths and styles for each side of the border.

remarks.p: When this property is set, then the reference to the original BorderDetails object remains the same, and BorderDetails-subproperties are copied using the "BorderDetails.CopyFrom(...)" method.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.ScrollButtons
member.summary: Appearance and behavior of buttons used to scroll tabs.

remarks.p: That property has effect only when is set to the Scrollable and orientation of tabs is horizontal. See .

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.AsyncMode
member.summary: Disable or enable hidden asynchronous post backs.

remarks.p: That property has effect only for Tabs which ContentPanes have child controls.

Warning: If error or exception happens on server or on client and that property is enabled, then full post backs can be triggered. In case of errors or other misbehavior,- that property should be disabled.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.AsyncOptions
member.summary: Options related to hidden asynchronous post backs.

remarks.p: That property has effect only if AsyncMode is On and only for Tabs which ContentPanes have child controls.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.About
member.summary: Display the about dialog.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.Infragistics#WebUI#Shared#IUltraLicensedComponent#License
member.summary: Return the license we cached inside the contructor.

summary.p: Returns or sets a value to determine whether a three-d border will be rendered around the tabs.

remarks.p: The ThreeD borders may not render in down-level browsers.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.BarHeight
member.summary: Height of the bar rendered between the tabs and the ContentPane.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.ImageDirectory
member.summary: Directory in which the images used for the tabs are stored.

remarks.p: The string specified as the ImageDirectory will be prefixed onto the , , and properties of the object.
Note that is a particular file-image-name starts with the ".", "/", "\\" character or contains the ":" character, then that file-name will be used as it is without the ImageDirectory prefix.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.TabOrientation
member.summary: Location and alignment of the tabs relative to the .

remarks.p: Permitted values are: TopLeft, TopRight, BottomLeft, BottomRight, LeftTop, LeftBottom, RightTop, RightBottom

Each TabOrientation constant specifies the orientation and the alignment of the Tab objects when rendered. E.g., TopLeft indicates the Tabs will be oriented on the Tab of the control and aligned to the left.

summary.p: Returns or sets the Orientation of the text within the

remarks.p: Permitted values are Horizontal and Vertical.

In all Netscape browsers and browsers prior to version 6.0 Vertical text indicates that the text will be rendered such that each letter is on a new line from top to bottom. On IE6 the text will be rotated 90 degrees clockwise.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.JavaScriptFileName
member.summary: Name of the file that contains the external JavaScript for client-side functionality on up-level browsers such as IE5, Netscape6.

remarks.p: Use this property to change the name of the external JavaScript file.
If the value of this property is set to the empty string, then the default value is used.
If the value is 1-3 characters long, then dynamic client functionality becomes disabled, however, the page is posted back on tab-click events.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.JavaScriptFileNameCommon
member.summary: Name of the file that contains the external JavaScript with common methods for client-side functionality on up-level browsers such as IE5, Netscape6.

remarks.p: Use this property to change the name of the common external JavaScript file.

If the application uses any other instance of any Infragistics Web control, then the values of that property in all controls should match, otherwise, client-side functionality in all controls may fail.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.BrowserTarget
member.summary: Type of browser the html should be created for.

remarks.p: Permitted values are DownLevel, UpLevel, and Auto.
The default value for this property is Auto which will detect the client browser and renders the output deemed appropriate for that browser.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.AutoPostBack
member.summary: Trigger a post back event when the selected tab is changed (on tab click).

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.ViewStateBias
member.summary: This property is deprecated and has no effect.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.SelectedTab
member.summary: Index of the currently selected tab.

remarks.p: Note: Separators are skipped. Only tabs are considered. For example, if there is a separator between 1st and 2nd tabs and 2nd tab is selected, then this property will return value 1, but index of that TabItem within Tabs collection is equal to 2.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.SelectedTabIndex
member.summary: Index of the currently selected tab within TabItems.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.SelectedTabObject
member.summary: Reference to the currently selected tab.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.LoadAllTargetUrls
member.summary: Load all TargetUrls assigned to tabs at the time when the page is loaded or keep loaded only one TargetUrl for the active/selected tab.

remarks.p:
In case of value true, all TargetUrls assigned to tabs are loaded and while dynamic navigation between tabs is used, the fields on tabs will keep old values. It means that if the TargetUrl on one tab was modified and submitted to a server, then fields on another tab will not reflect those changes and contain old initial values.
In case of the value false, only one TargetUrl which is assigned to the active tab is loaded. If while navigating between tabs the previous TargetUrl was not submitted, then changes in fields on that TargetUrl become lost.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.CustomRules
member.summary: Returns or sets a string of text that determines additional CSS rules to apply to the ContentPane of the tabs.
member.p: This is available only for up-level browsers and the tag of html element to which rules are applied is <TD>.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.DummyTargetUrl
member.summary: Name of the dummy url that is used as the src for the IFRAME object when the TargetUrl of a Tab is not set.

remarks.p: Default value is set to the "dummy.htm".

If the value is set to the empty string, then <IFRAME> elements are not written to html for tabs with an empty TargetUrl. In this situation the client side function setTargetUrl is not available for those tabs.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.DynamicTabs
member.summary: Keep a row with the selected tab closest to the ContentPane.

remarks.p: This property has effect only when tabs are located in multiple rows. See and .

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.DisplayMode
member.summary: The appearance of tabs such as SingleRow/MultiRow/Scrollable for tabs with horizontal orientation. See .

remarks.p:
Notes:
Multi-row tabs are available only for horizontal orientation of tabs and they are not automatic: the property should be used.
Scrollable tabs are available only for horizontal orientation of tabs.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.SpaceOnRight
member.summary: Space between the right side of UltraWebTab and the right edge of the last Tab.

remarks.p:
Notes:
This property has effect only for TopRight, BottomRight, LeftBottom and RightBottom orientations of tabs. See .
This property has effect also when is set to the MultiRow and orientation of tabs is horizontal.
This property has no effect if the last TabItem (right edge) is instance of TabSeparator.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.SpaceOnLeft
member.summary: Space between the left side of UltraWebTab and the left edge of the first Tab.

remarks.p:
Notes:
This property has effect only for TopLeft, BottomLeft, LeftTop and RightTop orientations of tabs. See .
This property has no effect if the 1st TabItem (left edge) is instance of TabSeparator.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.FixedLayout
member.summary: Fixed or automatic layout of a html-table that represents the UltraWebTab control.

remarks.p:
Notes for the value of true:
The width of control is defined by the value of the Width property, and tabs on the right can become inaccessible until the is set to Scrollable.
Painting problems are possible if the Height of is not set or has too small value.
The scrollable behavior of every individual can be customized by the property.

summary.p: Set or gets a value that determines whether Section 508 compliant html will be emitted.

remarks.p: Section 508 compliance provides for support of assistive technologies that make html pages accessible for users that require it.

summary.p: The tab order of control.

remarks.p: This property is supported only for InternetExplorer, which allows the setting of focus to the <TD> html element.
When tab-order is enabled, then left/right arrows, Home and End keys become enabled as well.
When that property has its default value of 0, then the property will enable or disable tab-order features.
If the property is set to a negative value, then tab-order functionality is disabled regardless of the property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.AccessKey
member.summary: Keyboard shortcut used by the control.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.StylePreset
member.summary: Configure appearance related properties using predefined values.

remarks.p: Note: The value of this property is not written to the ViewState and, therefore, it is not persistant between sessions. However, that property modifies many other (appearance related) properties, which are persistant between sessions if the ViewState is enabled. It means that if this property is set at run time, then it will result in significant increase of the size of the hidden-view-state-field which is passed to the client.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.IsAsyncPostBack
member.summary: Check if it is an asynchronous post back and if it was triggered and processed by this control.

remarks.p: If a value of true is returned, then it means that the postback was triggered by a child control of ContentPane of a Tab, or by a selected tab change event.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.EnableAppStyling
member.summary: Enables support on WebTab for the Application Styling Framework(tm).
member.value: True indicates Application Styling is enabled, False indicates Application Styling is disabled, and NotSet indicates support for Application Styling should default to page- or application-level settings.

remarks.p: Turn on support for Application Styling of WebTab when using the Application Styling Framework(tm) (ASF) by setting the EnableAppStyling property to True.

When EnableAppStyling has it's default value of NotSet, this control will defer the determination of whether to use Application Styling to settings you make at the page- or application-level. Place the WebPageStyler control on the same Web form as this control to configure ASF support for all controls on that Page. ASF support can also be turned on application-wide with the enableAppStyling attribute in your "web.config" file.
Turn off support for the ASF in WebTab (even though it may have been enabled at a higher level) by setting the EnableAppStyling property to False.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.StyleSetName
member.summary: Name of the Application Styling Framework(tm) style set defining the themed appearance for this WebTab control.

value.p: The name of the Application Styling Framework(tm) (ASF) style set which has been designed to give this control a consistent appearance with other controls in your application.
This property may return the empty string ("") to imply that the default style set (named "Default") should be used.

remarks.p: Web sites can configure a single, consistent, application-wide style set through the styleSetName attribute in their "web.config" file. Alternately, they can define the style set to apply Application Styling to all controls on a Page by placing a WebPageStyler control on that Page and setting it's StyleSetName property.
At the control level this property allows an application developer to customize the style set applied to a single instance of a control.

Normally, graphics designers will furnish you with a style set containing one or more style sheet files (one for each type of control) and image files. The name of the style set (with the exception of the "Default" style set) must appear in each Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) class name defined by this control's style sheet file. For example, two WebTree controls that each use a different style set, "Aqua" and "Onyx", would expect their CSS class names for the ASF Node role to be "igtr_AquaNode" and "igtr_OnyxNode", respectively. This allows the uniqueness of CSS class names necessary to distinguish multiple style sets for the same type of control, without there being any naming collisions.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.UltraWebTab.StyleSetPath
member.summary: Path containing the Application Styling Framework(tm) style set files for this type of control.

remarks.p: Web sites can configure the directory path containing their style set files application-wide by using the styleSetPath attribute of their "web.config" file. It is also possible to configure the style set path applicable to all controls on a Page that are subject to Application Styling by placing a WebPageStyler control on that Page and setting it's StyleSetPath property.
At the control level this property allows an application developer to customize the location of the style set being applied to a single instance of a control.

Be aware that customizing the style set path at the control level will not allow you to copy a style set's files to this new location, changing a few style property values in them, and then use it successfully with separate instances of the control referencing the original style set of the same name. This is because there would be naming collisions in the Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) class names, which will produce an undefined appearance. You must ensure the CSS class names defined by style sheets in the new style set path are unique from those CSS class names being used by other style sheets that may continue to be referenced. The recommended guidance in this scenario is to create a new style set having a new style set name, that contains your modifications.

member.summary: The options related to a response from a hidden asynchronous post back.

member.summary: The options related to actions that may trigger a hidden asynchronous post back.

remarks.p: Note: the ContentInitiatedPostback may work only for child controls that follow standards of dot-net related to postback and submit. The child should provide a UniqueID for those event handlers and it should render an html element with an id equal to the ClientID and it should be located inside of its container.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.AsyncOptions.EnableLoadOnDemand
member.summary: Enable the loading of ContentPanes of only the selected and last unselected tabs.

remarks.p: On initial load or after a full post back,- only the ContentPane of the selected tab is rendered.

Note: The states of fields (like TextBox) located on unselected tabs can not persist between postbacks, therefore, if an application needs up-to-date values of those fields, then that option can not be used.

Warning: That property may trigger full post backs and lead to errors, exceptions and other side effects. Therefore, application should test all possible scenarios. If an error happens, then this property should be disabled.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebTab.AsyncOptions.EnableProgressIndicator
member.summary: Enable progress indicator.

remarks.p: Note: To customize progress indicator, an application may use ClientSideEvents.InitializeTabs and set oWebTab.getProgressIndicator().setTemplate(innerHtml) or oWebTab.getProgressIndicator().setImageUrl(fileName). The location of indicator relative to tab-label can be set by oWebTab.getProgressIndicator().setLocation(ig_Location.aMemberConstantOrObjectWith_x_y)

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.CheckItems
member.summary: Implementation class used to store buttons belonging to a .

remarks.p: Applications may interact with this type as it has been exposed through the Buttons collection of a button group; but are not required to construct instances of this collection directly.

When creating dynamic instances of Toolbar items, developers must add the item to it's eventual collection prior to setting property values on the object. Certain complex properties (such as the DefaultStyle) of an item may not properly persist in viewstate across postbacks when they are attached to a Toolbar item before addition to a collection. The act of adding an item to a collection that is in contact with the UltraWebToolbar server control is what triggers tracking of viewstate.

member.summary: The index of the button in it's owning button group.

remarks.p: If the button does not exist within this group, -1 will be returned.
If multiple copies of the button have been added to this group, the lowest index of the first copy found will be returned.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.CheckItems.Add(Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBarButton)
member.summary: Adds a button to this collection.

remarks.p: Developers can call this method when they have previously created a and wish to add it to this button group's collection. Prior to setting any properties on a dynamically-created instance of , the developer must assign it to a collection. It's only at this point that viewstate-tracking can be performed.
When a button is added to the collection, it is linked to the which parents this collection.

member.param: The button to be added.
member.returns: The button which was added.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.CheckItems.Add(System.String)
member.summary: Adds a new button with the given text to this collection.
member.param: The text caption of the button added.

remarks.p: This method creates a new instance of and assigns it the specified text caption. When a button is added to this group's collection, it is linked to the which parents the collection.

member.returns: The button which was added.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.CheckItems.Add(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Adds a new button with the given text and key to this collection.
member.param: The text caption of the button added.
The key string used for looking-up this button.

remarks.p: This method creates a new instance of and assigns it the specified text caption and key string that can be used for flexible look-ups. Whenever buttons are added to this group's collection, they will be linked to the which parents the collection.

member.returns: The button which was added.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.CheckItems.FromKeyButton(System.String)
member.summary: Retrieves a button from the current button group based on that button's Key value.
member.param: The key value of the button being searched for.
member.returns: An instance of the first found with the given key, or null (Nothing in Visual Basic .NET) if no such button was found.

remarks.p: The comparison of the keys are case-sensitive.

It is the application developer's responsibility not to add buttons with the same Key value to the collection of toolbar items. For optimal performance and robustness, the avoidance of using duplicate keys within the same UltraWebToolbar is recommended.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.CheckItems.Remove(System.Object)
member.summary: Removes a button from this button group.
member.param: The button to be removed.

remarks.p: Equality checking of ob is based on Equals, and conventionally this does not identify s with equivalent keys. If an application holds what may be a cloned reference to a button present in this group, then developers are advised to use the method to locate the button within this collection and then call this method on that button object.
If an application needs to know whether ob was successfully removed, it should compare the pre-removal Count to the post-removal Count. On a successful removal, these two values are different.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.CheckItems.Insert(System.Int32,Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBarButton)
member.summary: Inserts a button into this group before the specified index.
member.param: Zero-based position at which to insert the button at.
The button to be inserted.

remarks.p: Developers are encouraged to use when adding items to the end of a group; this method supports inserting buttons before any given zero-based position within the group. Following a call to this method, btn will exist in the collection referenceable at index index, and all other Toolbar items following it will have their indices incremented by one.

Since changes in the membership of the collection can affect index-oriented referencing schemes in an application, developers are encouraged to assign items they wish to locate a Key value, and use the method.
remarks.exception: Thrown when index is less than 0, or exceeds the Count of items within this collection.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.ClientSideEvents
member.summary: Because of the stateless nature of web connections, and the typical delays involved in returning information from the server, UltraWebToolbar implements both client-side events and server-side events. You can choose whether you would like to respond to client-side events, which must be implemented through JavaScript. The ClientSideEvent object maintains a list of event handlers that are implemented on the client and called in response to events as they occur in the browser. Each event is a string that represents JavaScript function name. The named function must be implemented by the developer in JavaScript code. There are two obligatory parameters passed to every event function handler: Toolbar object and Item object. There may also be some additional parameters. Look at the events description for details.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.ClientSideEvents.Click
member.summary: Returns or sets a string of text that specifies the name of the JavaScript function to be called when a button is clicked on the client.

remarks.p: The name of the JavaScript function can be user defined or native. For example, to specify that the native function alert should be called, this property could be set to "alert('hello')." To specify that a user-defined function, myFunction, should be called, this property would be set to "myFunction."
A user-defined function must be defined either inline or in a linked JavaScript (.JS) file and can accept the following parameters:

dd.p: Object. The CSOM toolbar object calling the function.
Object. The CSOM object of the button that was clicked.

remarks.p: The parameters above are optional and can be named as desired.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.ClientSideEvents.ViewState
member.summary: Gets a dictionary of state information (StateBag) that allows you to save and restore the view state of a server control across multiple requests for the same page.

remarks.p: A server control's view state is the accumulation of all its property values. In order to preserve these values across HTTP requests, ASP.NET server controls use this property, which is an instance of the StateBag class, to store the property values. The values are then passed as a variable to an HTML hidden input element when subsequent requests are processed. For more information about saving server control view state, see Maintaining State in a Control.

Used to access the StyleSheetFileName and ParsedStyles properties of the control being rendered. These objects support references to CSS classes in external style sheets.
Used to fix-up style rules referencing images with the url() function, so that they look beneath the design-time path.

remarks.p: This constructor is public so that this class can be instantiated from controls residing in an external assembly. Your Web application should not call this constructor directly.

member.exception: Thrown when the styleSheetProvider argument is null (Nothing in Visual Basic .NET) A non-null styleSheetProvider is required to read an external CSS style sheet file name and parse it's styles.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.CssToInlineStyleReader.ReadLine
member.summary: Overridden. Reads a line from the input stream, filtering out portions of any <style> block and using definitions contained within any <style> block to replace appearances of the class attribute with an equivalent in-line style attribute.
member.returns: The filtered string, which may contain replacements of the class attribute, or which may be an empty string if a <style> block is being filtered out. Null (Nothing in Visual Basic .NET) when the stream has reached it's end.

remarks.p: The CssToInlineStyleReader class only overrides this method. Consumers wishing to filter their markup stream must repeatedly call this method until it returns null (Nothing in Visual Basic .NET).

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.BrowserTarget
member.summary: Determines the sophistication of HTML that should be rendered.

remarks.p: This enumeration lists the possible settings for the level of HTML (downlevel for maximum compatibility with older, less-capable user agents, uplevel for maximum performance and presentation on modern user agents). Values of this enumeration are assigned to the BrowserTarget property on the UltraWebToolbar element.

Troubleshooting an application experiencing the incorrect BrowserTarget for a particular brand, platform and version of a user agent when using the Auto setting can be done by checking the browser's brand, platform and version based on properties available through ASP.NET's HttpBrowserCapabilities class. This information is readable off of the HttpRequest during the Page_Load event, and developers may then manually set the appropriate browser level on for responses to that individual user agent only.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.BrowserTarget.Auto
member.summary: Makes an automatic determination of what degree of HTML, CSS and Javascript to render, by finding out the browser's type and version.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.BrowserTarget.DownLevel
member.summary: Renders HTML, with absolute minimal CSS and Javascript, that can be seen on down-level user agents. Developers may employ this setting when testing their web applications, to identify what experience end users on down-level user agents will have.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.BrowserTarget.UpLevel
member.summary: Renders HTML with CSS and Javascript, that displays itself best only on up-level user agents supporting dynamic HTML and Javascript.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TextAlign
member.summary: Enumeration of the alignment styles supported for text within a Toolbar item.

remarks.p: These enumerated values correspond to those supported by the CSS1 specification (§ 5.4.6) for the text-align attribute. If a user agent does not fully support text-align (for instance, the Justify setting), then it may substitute the default text alignment appropriate to the end user's cultural settings.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TextAlign.Left
member.summary: Content should be aligned to the left margin of the Toolbar item.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TextAlign.Center
member.summary: Content should be aligned in the center of the Toolbar item.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TextAlign.Right
member.summary: Content should be aligned to the right margin of the Toolbar item.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TextAlign.Justify
member.summary: Content should be evenly distributed within the space allocated.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TargetUrlTriggerMode
member.summary: List of transitions toggle buttons undergo, used by Web applications to customize when TargetUrl navigation happens.

remarks.p: Toggle buttons are instances with their ToggleButton property set to True. The behavior of navigating to the TargetURL property can occur on selection, deselection, or both state changes of the toggle button. For backwards compatibility with existing WebToolbar applications, the default behavior is OnToggleSelectOff.
Momentary buttons ignore the behaviors of this enumeration, any mouse click on these buttons triggers navigation to the TargetURL property, if any.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TargetUrlTriggerMode.OnToggleSelectOn
member.summary: Navigation is triggered when the toggle button becomes selected.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TargetUrlTriggerMode.OnToggleSelectOff
member.summary: Navigation is triggered when the toggle button becomes unselected (default).

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TargetUrlTriggerMode.OnToggleSelectEither
member.summary: Navigation is triggered both on every button click, whether the toggle button is selected or not selected.

remarks.p: This class is used within the Infragistics infrastructure, and it is not necessary to use this class from within your own applications.

An array of arguments supplied with which to initialize properties of the requested EventArgs instance. The number, sequence and type these arguments is dependent upon the applicable constructor offered by typeOfEvent.

remarks.p: When the return value of this method is non-null, the caller can safely typecase the object reference into an EventArgs subclass of the requested typeOfEvent.

Only group buttons, which act as a mutually-exclusive group, within a can fire the GroupButtonClicked event. Buttons within a TBButtonGroup do not fire the ButtonClicked event.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.LocationChangedEvent
member.summary: Event arguments notifying server-side logic of a change of screen position on the client-side.

remarks.p: This event is only fired following a postback for UltraWebToolbar controls that meet the following criteria:

list.item: The UltraWebToolbar is movable, otherwise its position is fixed.
The UltraWebToolbar is sticky, not snappable. A snappable toolbar will always return to its original location following each postback, therefore the old location on the client is inconsequential.
The UltraWebToolbar is being rendered to an uplevel browser.

member.name: F:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.LocationChangedEvent.Location
member.summary: The new location of the top-left corner of UltraWebToolbar on the client.

member.summary: Constructs a new instance of event arguments with a specific Point.

remarks.p: It should not be necessary for applications to create their own instances of arguments.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.LocationChangedEvent.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructs a new instance of event arguments with two specific coordinates.
member.param: The X-coordinate of the UltraWebToolbar's left-position.
The Y-coordinate of the UltraWebToolbar's top-position.

remarks.p: It should not be necessary for applications to create their own instances of arguments.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.VisibleChangingEvent
member.summary: Event arguments notifying subscribers of a server-side change in the Visible property of a TBarButton. Subscribers may cancel the change in property value.

remarks.p: Unlike other events on the UltraWebToolbar that provide notification of client-side activities (such as a button click or a toolbar drag) after Page_Load, the VisibleChangingEvent occurs in real-time to notify subscribers that the Visible property on a TBarButton has been modified.
This is a cancelable event. Any event handler that raises the Cancel flag on the VisibleChangingEvent arguments passed to that handler can prevent the newly assigned visibility from being accepted.

Developers may want to receive this event notification so they can reperform any necessary layout operations on the UltraWebToolbar to account for the change in the number of visible buttons it may contain.

Container classes that hold instances of TBarButton may also use the cancelation feature of this event notification to suppress changes to the Visible property of individual toolbar items if they have their own Visible property that must supercede the Visible states of their contents.

This event can only be fired when toolbar items attached to the UltraWebToolbar experience a change in their Visible property. No notice can be given when the Visible property is changed on a detached TBarButton.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.VisibleChangingEvent.#ctor(Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBarButton,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates an instance of the VisibleChangingEvent arguments in preparation for firing the event notification.
member.param: The instance of a TBarButton belonging to this UltraWebToolbar that has experienced a change in it's visibility settings.
The new visibility setting of targetButton.

remarks.p: It should not be necessary for applications to create their own instances of arguments.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.VisibleChangingEvent.NewValue
member.summary: The new visibility status of .
member.value: Returns true if Button has been made visible, false if it has been hidden.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.VisibleChangingEvent.OldValue
member.summary: The previous visibility status of .
member.value: Returns true if Button had been visible and is being hidden, otherwise it returns false when it was hidden and is now being shown.

remarks.p: If any event handler subscribed to the VisibleChanging event decides to cancel the property value change, then the visibility of Button shall continue to have this value following the event.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.VisibleChangingEvent.Button
member.summary: The TBarButton instance that is experiencing a change in it's visibility.

remarks.p: This button is guaranteed to be a member of the current UltraWebToolbar's Items collection, or a member of a TBButtonGroup that belongs to it's Items collection.
Developers handling the VisibleChanging event may examine the button and use the identity of the button to determine whether any special handling is necessary.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.IButtonFactory
member.summary: Factory interface that creates ITBarButton implementations and supports pluggable factory methods.

remarks.p: This interface supports two features:

list.item: Creating implementations through two construction methods.
Plugging in an alternative implementation of the two construction methods, to facilitate instantiating ITBarButton objects of an arbitrary type (not necessarily known a priori).

remarks.p: This interface is implemented by to support the creation, design-time and serialization support of button subclasses. It should not be necessary for application objects to implement this interface.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.IButtonFactory.Create
member.summary: Creates an instance of an ITBarButton with default characteristics.
member.returns: An object implementing ITBarButton, generally an instance of or one of its subclasses.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.IButtonFactory.Create(System.String)
member.summary: Creates an instance of an ITBarButton with the given Text property.
member.param: The string that will be given to the Text property of the ITBarButton-implementing object.
member.returns: An object implementing ITBarButton, generally an instance of or one of its subclasses.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.IButtonFactory.Create(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates an instance of an ITBarButton with the given Key property if such a button does not already exist.
member.param: The string that will be given to the Key property of the ITBarButton-implementing object.
A flag indicating whether the method should return an existing ITBarButton-implementing object if one already exists in a cache, instead of creating a new instance.
member.returns: An object implementing ITBarButton, generally an instance of or one of its subclasses.

remarks.p: An wrapper is created using this factory method when its not ordinarily desirable to create a new instance, but instead to reuse an existing button instance that may have already been cached. If no matching button instance can be found, this method instantiates a new instance of ITBarButton.

A conforming implementation may ignore the useCache argument when is false. In this case, this factory method behaves as if no matching button could be found in the cache (it must create a new instance).

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.IButtonFactory.HasCache
member.summary: Whether the factory method implementation supports cacheing of previously manufactured button instances.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.IButtonFactory.FactoryMethod
member.summary: Replaces the current implementation of the factory methods with the implementation of the IButtonFactoryPlugIn.

remarks.p: Proper implementation of requires that the and methods be delegated to the supplied implementation.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.IButtonFactoryPlugIn
member.summary: Factory interface that creates ITBarButton implementations.

remarks.p: If your application subclasses and adds instances of this subclass to , then you should provide an implementation of this interface to the containing UltraWebToolbar. This permits the Control to create instances of your subclass when necessary to provide serialization and design-time support without having to know explicit details of that subclass (such as its namespace, fully-qualified type, or assembly).
Typically, your implementation of the methods in this interface must only call the constructor of your subclass, and return a new object reference.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.IButtonImagePropertyProvider.RequiresChangeIndicators
member.summary: Indicates whether the provider requires consumers to report on whether image properties have been assigned a non-default value.
member.value: True if the provider needs to ask the consumer about the state of button image URL property values; otherwise False.

remarks.p: Tells the IButtonImagePropertyProvider consumer receiving this implementation that the provider of image properties requires an indication of whether image properties have changed from their default state. Consumers that support this functionality are required to assign an implementation of IButtonImagePropertySpecifiedFlagProvider to the property when this property is true. Consumers that cannot support the requirement expressed by this property must throw a NotSupportedException. A consumer would ordinarily obtain this information by setting a flag for the image URL properties to true when any value is set on them that may be from the application.

Support of this property makes possible proper handling of cases where applications may assign a blank value to certain image properties (such as HoverImage) intending to turn off the image, instead of getting it's default setting.

member.exception: Thrown when the IButtonImagePropertyProvider receiving the implementation does not support indication of whether image properties have been changed from their initial state.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.IButtonImagePropertyProvider.SpecifiedFlags
member.summary: Gets or sets the bridge established by the consumer when RequiresChangeIndicators is true for this provider to facilitate the provider pulling information from the consumer about whether image properties have been explicitly assigned any value.
member.value: Null (or Nothing in Visual Basic .NET) when the RequiresChangeIndicators property is false, or when the consumer doesn't support the requested functionality.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.IButtonImagePropertySpecifiedFlagProvider
member.summary: Interface provides information about whether button image URL properties have had values explicitly set upon them by the application.

remarks.p: This type supports the internal Infragistics control infrastructure, and is not intended for use by application developers.
Note: This interface may be subject to change without notice.

member.summary: Image applied to a default button in the normal (or "up") state.

remarks.p: Using this property is preferable to using the Image property because you can set alternate text to make the button more accessible for users when Section 508 rendering is turned on.
Alternate text on the button's image produces a tool tip in most browsers, which may supercede any setting made to the button's property when the user hovers above the graphic image of a button.

member.summary: Indicates whether ASP.NET should serialize these ButtonImageUrls.

member.summary: Resets the ButtonImageUrls to their default settings.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.ButtonImageUrls.SelectedImage
member.summary: Image applied when the button is in the depressed or down state.

remarks.p: Using this property is preferable to using the SelectedImage property because you can set alternate text to make the button more accessible for users when Section 508 rendering is turned on.
Unless the button is a toggle button, the button's selected state is only momentary and the button pops back up to use it's in the normal up state.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.ButtonImageUrls.HoverImage
member.summary: Image applied when the button is being moused over.

remarks.p: This image is displayed temporarily when the user mouses over an enabled, unselected button. After the mouse leaves the button the image reverts to the .

Because mouse over is a temporary visual embellishment not intended to convey extra information, the alternate text on HoverImage is not rendered. Instead users will continue to witness any alternate text and tool tip rendered by the default image.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.ButtonImageUrls.DisabledImage
member.summary: Image applied when the button has been disabled.

remarks.p: Using this property is preferable to using the DisabledImage property because you can set alternate text to make the button more accessible for users when Section 508 rendering is turned on.
Applications should set alternate text for a disabled button indicating functionality provided by the button is unavailable in order to best comply with Section 508 accessibility requirements.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.Items
member.summary: Primary collection of Toolbar items belonging to the UltraWebToolbar element.

remarks.p: The items constituting the UltraWebToolbar may be of varied types, including: , , , , , and wrappers around any additional System.Web.UI.Control.

All of these supported types, except for TBCustom, are derived from the base class, . The TBCustom type is derived from WebControl permitting it to act as a host (container) of other ASP.NET controls.

The Items collection offers both integer-based indexing of its contents, as well as Key-based retrieval. For the most flexible and robust applications, developers are encouraged to assign a unique Key to each item added to the collection and then use or a related method (i.e., , et al.) to lookup items.

When creating dynamic instances of Toolbar items, developers must add the item to it's eventual collection before making property settings on the item. Certain complex properties (such as the DefaultStyle) may not properly persist in viewstate across postbacks when they are attached to a Toolbar item before it has been included in a collection attached to the server control (as the Items is attached). The act of adding an item to this collection, precisely because it is in direct contact with the UltraWebToolbar element, is what triggers tracking of viewstate for these properties.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.Items.AddLabel(System.String)
member.summary: Adds an UltraWebToolbar label to the collection with the specified text caption.
member.param: The static text appearing in the TBLabel.
member.returns: The newly created instance, which developers may further customize.

remarks.p: Developers should use this method to add a new, dynamically-created TBLabel to the left-end of the UltraWebToolbar element. The label's Text property will be initialized to the value given by the text argument.

Use the method to insert a new instance of TBLabel before (to the left of) other Toolbar items. When calling Insert, the developer is responsible for creating the TBLabel instance beforehand, and setting its Text property afterwards.

member.param: The text caption displayed by the TBLabel.
The key value identifying the TBLabel, it should be unique across this UltraWebToolbar element.
member.returns: The newly created instance, which developers may further customize.

remarks.p: Developers should use this method to add a new, dynamically-created TBLabel to the left-end of the UltraWebToolbar element. The label's Text property will be initialized to the value given by the text argument.

Use the method to insert a new instance of TBLabel before (to the left of) other Toolbar items. When calling Insert, the developer is responsible for creating the TBLabel instance beforehand, and setting its Text and Key properties afterwards.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.Items.FromKeyButton(System.String)
member.summary: String indexer for the Toolbar items collection based on the Key property.
member.returns: An instance of the first found with the given key, or null (Nothing in Visual Basic .NET) if no such button was found.

remarks.p: This indexer method is deprecated because it does not properly support subclassed buttons. Developers should employ where possible to make their web applications more flexible.

When an item of the given key is found, a check is performed of whether it is of type . If the matching item is not of the correct type, null is returned. When duplicate keys are present across items of different types, an object present in the collection may be reported not found if the first object matching key has a different type.
The comparison of the keys are performed in a case-sensitive manner.

It is the application developer's responsibility not to add buttons with the same Key value to the collection of toolbar items. For optimal performance and robustness, the avoidance of duplicate key use within the same UltraWebToolbar is strongly recommended.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.Items.FromKeyIButton(System.String)
member.summary: String indexer for the Toolbar items collection based on the Key property that returns instances of ITBarButton.

remarks.p: The comparison of the keys are performed in a case-sensitive manner.
When an item of the given key is found, a check is performed of whether it is of a type implementing . If the matching item is not of an expected type, null is returned.

It is the application developer's responsibility not to add buttons with the same Key value to the collection of toolbar items. For optimal performance and robustness, the avoidance of duplicate key use within the same UltraWebToolbar is strongly recommended.
If the web application places subclassed instances into the UltraWebToolbar element, then it should uniformly use this indexer to access those items.

It is the application developer's responsibility not to add button groups having identical Key values to this collection of toolbar items. For optimal performance and robustness, the avoidance of duplicate key use within the same UltraWebToolbar is strongly recommended.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.Items.FromKey(System.String)
member.summary: String indexer for the Toolbar items collection based on the Key property that returns generic Toolbar Items.

remarks.p: The first Toolbar item encountered matching key is returned. As button groups are encountered within the collection, if the button group's Key is not a match, then the buttons contained by that button group are checked next, before ensuing items present in this collection.
The comparison of the keys are performed in a case-sensitive manner.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.IStatefulDictionary
member.summary: Contractual obligations of stateful dictionaries that act as proxies for the state retained by Toolbar items, before and after their inclusion into a Collection that is attached to the UltraWebToolbar element.

remarks.p: Toolbar items each maintain an internal IStatefulDictionary implementation through which they route their ViewState properties. This stateful dictionary can be implemented as any concrete dictionary, and tracks changes to property values up to and until the Toolbar item is added to a Collection associated with the UltraWebToolbar element. Once a Toolbar item is added to a collection, the control infrastructure replaces the dictionary with a StateBag so that all property changes to that point are retained when tracking viewstate.

It is not necessary for applications to implement IStatefulDictionary directly, however inheritors subclassing the base Toolbar item types may need to interact with their base class' ViewState property, and in those cases, knowledge of how this interface operates may be informative.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.IStatefulDictionary.SetItemDirty(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets an entry of the dictionary to dirty status.
member.param: Identifies the property to dirty, this is usually the name of the property (although it may be an abbreviation of the property's name).
When true, the property is considered dirty and will be persisted in viewstate if is called.

remarks.p: This will set an item to dirty status without a corresponding Value being assigned; the developer should always associate a Value with a dirtied property.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.IStatefulDictionary.GetStateBag
member.summary: Gets the viewstate bag belonging to the associated Toolbar item when it tracks state.
member.returns: A StateBag with all the keys and values of the IStatefulDictionary, or null (Nothing in Visual Basic .NET) before has been called.

remarks.p: Use this accessor when implementing IStateManager to make use of the IStateManager of the viewstate bag.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.IStatefulDictionary.Track
member.summary: Turns on tracking of changes to the property values of the associated Toolbar item.

remarks.p: Calling this method is what converts the underlying implementation of the to use viewstate tracking over a stateful proxy.
After calling this method, must be true. Calling this method multiple times should have no effect.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.IStatefulDictionary.Flush
member.summary: Clears any record of assignments to properties made before the call to Flush.

remarks.p: This method is called on a StatefulDictionary when it belongs to a static Toolbar item and the Init event fires on the UltraWebToolbar. It signifies that all values assigned prior to this point came from the web form itself, and do not need to be persisted in viewstate (thereby keeping the size of viewstate to a minimum).
An implementation may ignore a flush request made after it has already turned on tracking of the view state by calling .

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.IStatefulDictionary.IsTracking
member.summary: Indicates the stateful dictionary is tracking changes to it's associated Toolbar item's properties.
member.value: This flag is irrevocably true after a call to ; prior to Track being called this flag is always false.

member.summary: Whether an item in viewstate is regarded as dirty or not.
member.param: The name of the property.
A flag that is true when the item should be marked dirty, and false when the item should be laundered (removed from the stateful dictionary if it is present).

member.summary: Retrieves the StateBag containing the property value assignments, when tracking viewstate.
member.returns: A StateBag, or null (Nothing in Visual Basic .NET) if has not been called.

remarks.p: Callers should poll before directly operating with it in a manner presuming the existence of a StateBag, and call prior to . This is required in LoadViewState.

member.exception: Thrown when GetStateBag has been called prior to .

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.Style
member.summary: Class implementing CSS style attributes and functionality for the UltraWebToolbar element.

remarks.p: This class extends Infragistics.WebUI.Shared.Style, which itself extends the base ASP.NET Framework Style class. These extensions add support for text alignment, and properties providing developers with finely tuned control over the padding between, margins within, and per-edge border characteristics of Toolbar items.

Developers creating dynamic instances of Style should fully-qualify the type with the Infragistics.WebUI.UltraWebToolbar namespace. In many cases, applications will import the System.Web.UI.WebControls namespace (which includes the base Style class), and the presence of both types can lead to a naming conflict.

The DefaultStyle, SelectedStyle, and HoverStyle properties cannot accept instances of the base class, System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style, and will instead produce a CS0029 or BC30311 compilation error on any such assignment. This error can be corrected by fully-qualifying the type name to be Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.Style.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.Style.IsEmpty
member.summary: Indicates whether the Style is empty.
member.returns: True if the Style has all of its default values.

remarks.p: An empty style is one that exists (it is not null, or Nothing in Visual Basic .NET), but has all default property values. As a result, a savings can be realized by not serializing the style information to viewstate.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.Style.CopyFrom(System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style)
member.summary: Copy style properties from source into current style object.
member.param: Style acting as the source of new properties to copy.

remarks.p: Overridden to copy properties added to the Style type by the UltraWebToolbar control, such as .

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.Style.MergeWith(Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.Style,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Merges a supplied Style object into the current Style.
member.param: The Style that is to be merged into the current instance.
The BorderColor shall remain untouched during the merge.

remarks.p: In general, this merge operation replaces any NotSet or empty properties of the current Style instance with those of the mergeStyle.
If any Font characteristics (i.e., boldness or underscore) are enabled on the current Style, then they remain enabled (even if they are disabled on the mergeStyle).

This merge method is not of sufficiently fine granularity to parse the CustomRules, and apply only differences or additions from the mergeStyle. If the current Style has no CustomRules, then it accepts the CustomRules of the mergeStyle, otherwise the mergeStyle's CustomRules are entirely disregarded.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.Style.TextAlign
member.summary: Determines the alignment of text displayed by a Toolbar item.

remarks.p: The default text alignment applied to Toolbar items is Center, because the length of any text within them is generally static (it does not change) and they can consistently appear centered within the item's allocated Width. If the length of text for an item (label, text box, etc.) is subject to change, then designers may consider setting a value from the TextAlign enumeration to this property to make the Toolbar item appear consistent across changes. This layout may additionally involve increasing the Margin.Left to add space between left-aligned text and the previous Toolbar item.

UltraWebToolbar does not auto-detect whether the end user's cultural settings suggest a left-to-right or right-to-left writing system. Developers with this requirement may institute RTL language detection by reading the UserLanguages off of the HTTP request during the initial Page_Load, and setting TextAlign on the Toolbar items as appropriate.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBarButton
member.summary: The TBarButton object is the mos common type of item used in the toolbar. It renders like a button that the user can press to invoke a command. The TBarButton behaves much like an HTML button, but gives you the ability to include images, keep state, and customize borders.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBFocusable
member.summary: The base class for all Toolbar objects that are interactive and can receive focus.

remarks.p: This class exists in the inheritance hierarchy to provide common tab stop functionality for interactive user elements while excluding same from .

Since is not in the TBObject inheritance hierarchy, it does not share this functionality. However, most child controls that the Developer embeds within the WebToolbar as TBCustom objects have support for their own tab order processing.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBObject
member.summary: Abstract base class for all Toolbar items, except .

remarks.p: Developers can add one or more instances of TBObject's subclasses either at design-time (where they are serialized into the underlying web form), or at run-time, by adding them to the polymorphic UltraWebToolbar.Items container collection. There are subclasses that satisfy many requirements of the kinds of tools commonly present through toolbar user interfaces.
UltraWebToolbar elements may also contain custom web controls that derive from the System.Web.UI.Control class. However, these must be hosted within a wrapper, which is not a subclass of TBObject.

member.summary: Retains state and serves as a proxy for the bag prior to this Toolbar item being added to a collection attached to the UltraWebToolbar element.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBObject.Clone
member.summary: Creates and returns a deep copy of this object.
member.returns: A deep copy of this object.

remarks.p: This method creates a cloned copy of the base object. It copies all base class property values assigned to the calling instance of TBObject.

It handles cloning of the Tag property specially. If a reference-type object is assigned to the Tag, and it implements ICloneable, then it will be deeply cloned. Otherwise its reference is shallow copied.

Developers must exercise caution with their handling of cloned instances. In particular, cloned instances may be difficult to find by object reference-equality tests when they've been placed into collections.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBObject.ID
member.summary: Returns an index-based ID for this Toolbar item.

remarks.p: An item's ID is comprised of the UltraWebToolbar's ID, and this object's Index in the Items collection at run-time. If the item is a grouped button, then the ID has two levels: the index of the button group within Items and the index of the button within the group's Buttons collection. This property value is volatile if the Items collection is modified.

For more robust and flexible applications, developers are encouraged to specify a value and use one of the methods on Toolbar item collections such as Items or Buttons to locate individual TBObject instances. A shortcoming of retaining index-based references to Toolbar items is that they are susceptible to becoming invalid when the container collection has had its contents manipulated (via it's Add or Remove methods).
Indexes for items contained by the UltraWebToolbar element are always zero-based, meaning that the first item in a collection will have an index number of 0.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBObject.Parent
member.summary: Gets a reference to this Toolbar item's parent.

remarks.p: The parent could be the UltraWebToolbar, or if this item is a inside of a , the TBButtonGroup it belongs to.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBObject.Tag
member.summary: Arbitrary data object storing extra information to meet application-specific demands.

remarks.p: This property is provided as a convenience for developers to annotate (or "tag") individual Toolbar items with arbitrary data objects during the processing of an HTTP request.
If the Tag object is a Common Language Runtime (CLR) reference-type, then developers are encouraged to implement ICloneable on its type to properly support deep copies made by the method.

In order for the Tag object to persist itself within viewstate across postbacks, it must either be marked with the Serializable attribute, or implement ISerializable. Please consult the .NET Framework SDK for more information on serialization.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBFocusable.TabIndex
member.summary: Identifies at what position within the page tab order this user element receives focus.

remarks.p: Default value is -2 and it means that tab order is defined by the TabIndex property of UltraWebToolbar.

The value of -1 will disable tab order for this object. Developers may specify a tab index so that this element is navigable through the tab order by end users employing the TAB and Alt-TAB shortcut keys.
No checking is performed as to whether the tabIndex value assigned to this property by the developer is unique. The effect of assigning duplicate tabIndex values on a web page is undefined.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBFocusable.AccessKey
member.summary: Keyboard access key for this item.

remarks.p: The action that occurs is equivalent to the mouse click on this item.
The access-key is the feature of a browser, which is triggered by the keyboard entry of Alt+key.
That property is supported only for InternetExplorer, which allows to set focus to the <TD> html element.
If the <u> string is not found in the Text of this item and the value of AccessKey is set as the UPPER-case-letter, then the first found access-character in the Text is rendered with underscore.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBarButton.AutoPostBack
member.summary: Determines whether this individual button should postback when clicked.

remarks.p: Normally when there are any server-side button click handlers attached to the UltraWebToolbar, a postback ensues. This property permits individual buttons to manage whether the control posts back in response to the end user clicking on them. The recommended use of AutoPostBack is to declaratively determine whether an individual button posts back at design-time, and use an event handler only when the determination to postback depends upon data known only at run-time.

Developers must leave this property set to its default value, true, if their application relies upon detecting button clicks on this button via a server-side button clicked event handler. Alternately, buttons of no interest to server-side event handlers may shunt what might be an unnecessary postback by setting AutoPostBack to false resulting in an improved client-side experience.

The client-side behavior of AutoPostBack respects client-side event handlers which may independently assign the needPostBack property on their event object to coerce a postback. This promotes backwards-compatibility with legacy applications already using needPostBack for this purpose.
AutoPostBack does not apply to s that are grouped into a , therefore the property setting is ignored by grouped buttons.

When modifying AutoPostBack on the client-side, the change applies until a postback occurs. Developers should make no assumption about whether the modification will persist across postback, as the persistence of client-side changes to this property are formally undefined.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBarButton.Enabled
member.summary: Determines if this button should appear enabled and react to user input.

remarks.p: When Enabled is set to false, a button's appearance will stay static. No or will be applied. If the property is set, that image will be displayed instead of the default .

exception.p: Thrown when the Enabled property of the parent ToolBar is set to False, and an assignment is made to this property attempting to enable a TBarButton on the disabled toolbar.
When the parent ToolBar is disabled, a snapshot of the enabled states of all contained TBarButtons is taken. This snapshot is restored when the ToolBar is re-enabled.
Changes made to the state of this property while the toolbar is disabled are discarded. In particular, attempting to enable this item under these circumstances is invalid.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBarButton.TargetFrame
member.summary: Used to determine what frame the should be displayed in.

remarks.p: You can specify an HTML frame, an object such as an IFrame, or use "_blank" to launch in a new window.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBarButton.TargetURL
member.summary: A URL which will be navigated to, when this button is clicked.

remarks.p: When set, the TargetURL is displayed in the frame specified by the property.

The TargetURL should be a fully qualified Uniform Resource Locator, for example, "http://www.infragistics.com". If the URL lacks a protocol specifier (i.e., http://) it will be treated as a relative address (for example, the filename of another web page in the same directory as the current web application).

Additionally, developers may use this property to make a script call by prefixing a language specifier recognized by the end user's browser. An example of calling a JavaScript function named myFunction would look like this:
TargetURL="javascript:myFunction()";

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBarButton.ToggleButton
member.summary: Determines if the button should keep its state. When true, the button will remain depressed after first being clicked. Clicking the button again will restore the button to its normal state.

remarks.p: Setting this to True, will cause the button to be selected on the first click, and the second click will unselect the button. When set to False, a button will only stay selected while the mouse button is pressed down.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBarButton.TargetUrlTriggerMode
member.summary: Defines when TargetUrl navigation takes place for toggle buttons.
member.value: An indication of when toggle buttons should navigate to their TargetUrl.

remarks.p: When TargetURL is set to a URL to take an end user to when that user presses a button, and the TargetFrame is set such that the new URL will appear in a frame or new window (i.e., the WebToolbar is not replaced meaning the user can still see the button's selected state), an application may want to customize which state transition (on the selection, or on the deselection) a toggle button navigates.

Toggle buttons are instances with their ToggleButton property set to True. Unlike momentary buttons, which present no selected state when the user releases their mouse button, a toggle button may appear either selected (down) or unselected (up).

Set this property if you want to change the behavior of a toggle button to navigate to it's TargetURL as it becomes selected, or for any mouse button click. For backwards compatibility with existing WebToolbar applications, the default behavior is OnToggleSelectOff.
Momentary buttons can disregard the behavior defined by this property. Any mouse click on these buttons triggers navigation to the TargetURL property immediately.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBarButton.Visible
member.summary: Indicates whether the current button renders itself to the browser.

remarks.p: Developers set Visible to False when they want to hide a button from the end user temporarily. The TBarButton continues to maintain its state on the server-side (if EnableViewState is True on the toolbar element). On subsequent postbacks, developers can un-hide the button to show it again.

A hidden button renders no HTML to the browser, therefore its position in the rendered toolbar will collapse (this may affect the layout of other buttons unless accounted for separately). Although the button's state persists through viewstate, it is not accessible to client-side script.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBButtonGroup
member.summary: Button groups represent several items with a mutually exclusive selection state. No more than one button within the group is selected at any time.

remarks.p: The TBButtonGroup maintains a collection of button objects within it's collection. The type is used to manage this collection and ensure it's mutually exclusive selection criterion (similar to radio button behavior). Each individual button added to the group has its Parent property set to its containing TBButtonGroup object. The currently selected button, if any, is available through the property.

Styles applied to the TBButtonGroup shall only affect the background of the group; it is still necessary to set styles upon the buttons that are added to the group. Any items added to the group do not automatically inherit the appearance of the group. Items are always rendered in front of the background of the group. For instance, if both the group and item specify a BackgroundImage, the background image of the item appears in front of the background image of the group. A portion of the group's background image may remain visible at the edges of the item, depending upon the values assigned for margins.

In order for the viewstate to be properly managed across postbacks, developers dynamically creating their and TBButtonGroup objects are strongly advised to add them to the UltraWebToolbar's Items collection before setting the property values on them. Many complex property types (cf, DefaultStyle) cannot properly track viewstate until they have been connected to the UltraWebToolbar control.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBButtonGroup.Clone
member.summary: Creates a deep copy of this object.
member.returns: A deep copy of this object.

remarks.p: This method creates a cloned copy of the object, including clones of all instances in its collection. It copies all property values and styles. If a reference-type object is assigned to the Tag property, and it implements ICloneable, then it will be deeply cloned, otherwise its reference is shallow copied.
Developers must exercise caution with their handling of cloned instances.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBButtonGroup.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a Button Group with an empty collection of buttons.

remarks.p: After creating a TBButtonGroup, it is essential that it immediately be added to the Items collection on the UltraWebToolbar prior to it being receiving buttons or having it's property values set. Failure to do so may result in changes to the button group not being properly reflected in viewstate.
Following this, developers may want to assign a Key to the button group to make it easy to locate within the Items collection.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBButtonGroup.GetDefStyleClsName
member.summary: Retrieves the CSS class name associated with the default style.
member.returns: CSS class name.

remarks.p: The renderer economically emits repetitive style information by using CSS (Cascading Style Sheet) classes that it renders in a <STYLE> block when it renders the UltraWebToolbar element. Developers subclassing may discover the CSS class name to be produced at render-time for the default style of the button group, or override this member to introduce their own default CSS class. While CSS classes follow a recognizable naming pattern, this pattern is subject to change.
The recommended practice (instead of having to subclass TBButtonGroup) is to introduce a default CSS class by assigning one directly to the CssClass sub-property of .
