member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBButtonGroup.SelectedButton
member.summary: Selected button of this group.

remarks.p: Setting this property also sets the button's Selected property to the proper value. The formerly selected button will have its Selected set to false, while the newly selected button will have its Selected set to true.

If the button is already a member of a button group, then an application may alternately assign a value to the desired button's Selected directly. It is not necessary for an application to set both Selected and SelectedButton.

The selected button of the group remains unchanged, if the instance assigned to this property is not a member of this group. Membership is determined by reference equality, therefore if the application holds a cloned button instance, it may not be treated as a member of the group (developers should remove the button, by it's Key, from the collection and then re-insert their cloned button instance to the collection).

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBButtonGroup.Buttons
member.summary: The collection of buttons belonging to this group.

remarks.p: This property yields a collection of instances that are current members of this button group. Applications should access any of the buttons which belong to this group through this property, either by indexing it with the ordinal position of a button, or (preferably) by using one of the FromKeyButton methods of the collection object.
For example, the following VB.NET statement would return the first button in the group:
Dim myButton As TBarButton = myGroup.Buttons(0) ' Where myGroup is a object.
A corresponding indexing statement in C# looks like this:
TBarButton myButton = myGroup.Buttons[0]; // Where myGroup is a object.

Developers are strongly encouraged, however, to give their buttons unique Key values. This enables them to flexibly locate buttons even after the contents of a collection have been rearranged. The following VB.NET statement demonstrates how to use the FromKeyButton method to do so:
Dim myButton As TBarButton = myGroup.Buttons.FromKeyButton( "MyButtonKey")
In C#, a developer might write the following statement in this manner:
TBarButton myButton = myGroup.Buttons.FromKeyButton( "MyButtonKey");

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBButtonGroup.DefaultStyle
member.summary: The style used when rendering a group button by default.

remarks.p: The DefaultStyle is the style which is applied to a button in this group, when not selected, or moused over (e.g., in the "up" position). When explicitly set on the TBButtonGroup, the DefaultStyle overrides DefaultStyle on the UltraWebToolbar element, and is itself overridden by DefaultStyle on the object.
Designers may force the TBarButton to employ a specific style by assigning the name of a class to the CssClass property. Force the use of no style, by specifying "none" for the CssClass property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBButtonGroup.HoverStyle
member.summary: The style used when a group button in this group is moused over.

remarks.p: The HoverStyle is the style which is applied to a button in\ this group when moused over, if not (i.e., the end user's left mouse button is up). When set, HoverStyle overrides HoverStyle, on the UltraWebToolbar element, and is itself overridden by HoverStyle on the object.
Designers may force the TBarButton to employ a specific style by assigning the name of a class to the CssClass property. Force the use of no style, by specifying "none" for the CssClass property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBButtonGroup.SelectedStyle
member.summary: The style used when a group button in this group is depressed.

remarks.p: The SelectedStyle is the style which is applied to a group button when its is true, or the end user has positioned their mouse above this group button and clicked their left mouse button (causing the group button to temporarily exhibit a depressed appearance while the mouse button is down). If the group button's ToggleButton property is true, the SelectedStyle persists until the group button is clicked again.
SelectedStyle settings override the , on the UltraWebToolbar element, and it may be overridden by on the individual instances within the group.
Designers may force the TBarButton to employ a specific style by assigning the name of a class to the CssClass property. Force the use of no style, by specifying "none" for the CssClass property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBButtonGroup.HasDefaultStyle
member.summary: Indicates whether the Button group has an explicit default style.

remarks.p: This has an explicit style if the style exists (it is non-null), is non-empty (at least one value has been changed from the initialized appearance), and no CssClass has been assigned to override the property values of the style.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBButtonGroup.HasHoverStyle
member.summary: Indicates whether the Button group has an explicit hover style.

remarks.p: This has an explicit style if the style exists (it is non-null), is non-empty (at least one value has been changed from the initialized appearance), and no CssClass has been assigned to override the property values of the style.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBButtonGroup.HasSelectedStyle

remarks.p: This has an explicit style if the style exists (it is non-null), is non-empty (at least one value has been changed from the initialized appearance), and no CssClass has been assigned to override the property values of the style.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBCustom.Tag
member.summary: Arbitrary data object storing extra information to meet application-specific demands.

remarks.p: This property is provided as a convenience for developers to annotate (or "tag") individual Toolbar items with arbitrary data objects during the processing of an HTTP request.
If the Tag object is a Common Language Runtime (CLR) reference-type, then developers are encouraged to implement ICloneable on its type to properly support deep copies made by the method.

In order for the Tag object to persist itself within viewstate across postbacks, it must either be marked with the Serializable attribute, or implement ISerializable. Please consult the .NET Framework SDK for more information on serialization.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBCustom.Width
member.summary: Determines the width of the cell allocated to the contained custom control.

remarks.p: Failure to set this property, or ItemWidthDefault on the UltraWebToolbar element, may result in the toolbar expanding to fill the available space on it's right, to the edge of the browser window.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBLabel
member.summary: The TBLabel is a static text or image object that can be rendered within the UltraWebToolbar.

remarks.p: The TBLabel provides developers with the ability to place literal text or a static image within the UltraWebToolbar element. Some of its uses include creating horizontal space (although, see also ), displaying an image, or providing supplemental information to the end user on the state of some operation.

Because it is designed to be static and lightweight, TBLabel only exposes a . It does not react to mouse-over or button click events. In applications requiring a more dynamic visual presentation than TBLabel can provide, consider using the with it's Text property, but handle its click event by ignoring it to make it behave passively.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBLabel.Clone
member.summary: Creates a deep copy of this label.
member.returns: A deep copy of this label.

remarks.p: This method creates a cloned copy of the object, including a clone of its , if any. It copies all property values assigned to the calling instance of TBLabel.

It handles cloning of the Tag property specially. If a reference-type object is assigned to the Tag, and it implements ICloneable, then it will be deeply cloned. Otherwise its reference is shallow copied.

Developers must exercise caution with their handling of cloned instances. In particular, cloned instances may be difficult to find by object reference-equality tests when they've been placed into collections.

member.summary: The style which will be used when rendering this Label in the UltraWebToolbar.

remarks.p: When set, DefaultStyle overrides , on the UltraWebToolbar object. To force the UltraWebToolbar to your your own style, specify the name of your class in the CssClass property. To force the use of no style, specify "none" for the CssClass property.

member.summary: Indicates whether the Toolbar label has a default image specified.

remarks.p: This has a default image specified when it's property is set to a non-null, non-empty, relative URL to an image file. This method does not verify whether the URL specified is valid (if an invalid URL is specified for the image, a broken image link will appear to the end user).

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBLabel.ToolTip
member.summary: The text displayed momentarily after this label has been moused over by the end user.

remarks.p: The ToolTip will be rendered within a TITLE attribute; it takes precedence over any other settings for Section 508 (Accessibility) compliance.
Browser implementations are encouraged to display the TITLE attribute as a floating tooltip, however this feature may not be available in all browsers (or user agents).

member.summary: Separators provide visual separation between horizontally-arranged items within the UltraWebToolbar element.

remarks.p: Ordinarily, a plain vertical bar is rendered as the separator, however applications may specify the use of their own .
Developers may assign a to control the degree of horizontal spacing provided (setting a Width is frequently a requirement when an Image is specified) in user agents that support CSS styles.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBSeparator.Image
member.summary: A relative path to the Image which should be used as a graphical separator.

remarks.p: When set, this image will be displayed as a separator, instead of the default bar. If the image is wider than 8 pixels, developers should also set the property on the separator to prevent clipping.
Note: If the property is set, this path should be relative to the ImageDirectory.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBSeparator.Width
member.summary: The width of the separator, particularly when an Image should be used as a graphical separator.

remarks.p: By default, the width of 8px is used for a separator. However, if an is specified, developers may need to set an explicit value for this property to prevent the image from being clipped.

Note: Because UltraWebToolbar is rendered as a fixed-layout <table>, it is not recommended that Unit.Empty. Such a setting may lead to inconsistent layout across different browser platforms. The width of the image cannot be auto-detected.

member.summary: Gets a text representation of this object.
member.returns: The string representation, "TextBox."

remarks.p: This method is only used at design-time.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBTextBox.Clone
member.summary: Creates a deep copy of this text box.
member.returns: A deep copy of this text box.

remarks.p: This method creates a cloned copy of the object, including a clone of its , if any. It copies all property values assigned to the calling instance of TBTextBox.

It handles cloning of the Tag property specially. If a reference-type object is assigned to the Tag, and it implements ICloneable, then it will be deeply cloned. Otherwise its reference is shallow copied.

Developers must exercise caution with their handling of cloned instances. In particular, cloned instances may be difficult to find by object reference-equality tests when they've been placed into collections.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBTextBox.HasDefaultStyle
member.summary: Indicates whether this text box has an explicit default style.

remarks.p: This has an explicit style if the style exists (it is non-null), is non-empty (at least one value has been changed from the initialized appearance), and no CssClass has been assigned to override the property values of the style.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBTextBox.DefaultStyle
member.summary: The style which will be used when rendering this text box in the UltraWebToolbar.

remarks.p: When set, DefaultStyle overrides , on the UltraWebToolbar object. Developers may force the UltraWebToolbar to use their own style through specifying the name of their CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) class in the CssClass property. To force no style use, specify a value of "none" for the CssClass property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBTextBox.Text
member.summary: The text which will be displayed inside of this text box when rendered.

remarks.p: The manner in which the text is rendered depends upon the value of the property and the styles applied to the text box.

member.summary: Determines how many rows of text can be entered when the is MultiLine.

The use of this property has been deprecated.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.TBTextBox.Columns
member.summary: Use this property to determine how many characters wide the text box should be.

member.name: T:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar
member.summary: UltraWebToolbar server control that represents the horizontal button and accessories bar model within ASP.NET web applications.

remarks.p: This class represents the primary object of the UltraWebToolbar control. It is derived from the .NET Framework's WebControl object. UltraWebToolbar presents the top-level programming API through which the a web application interacts.
The Items collection of this control contains the set of toolbar items (incl. buttons, grouped buttons, toggle buttons, separators, labels, textboxes, and custom controls).

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.LoadPreset(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads a preset from a file that sets properties affecting appearance, behavior or both.
member.param: Fully specified absolute path to the preset file.
Whether to reset all properties on this control to their default values before applying the preset.

remarks.p: If you experience seemingly arbitrary properties "bleeding" through based on the order in which you apply more than one preset, then you should consider specifying the reset option to clear properties (where possible) before applying subsequent presets.
The reset mechanism depends on control properties having a corresponding Reset method implemented for themselves. It cannot reset properties that do not have a Reset method defined.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.TrackViewState
member.summary: Triggers the retention of viewstate changes for the UltraWebToolbar element.

remarks.p: Subclasses whose extensions also require them to override the UltraWebToolbar's implementation of IStateManager may need to override this method. Unless overriden, this method will trigger viewstate tracking of itself and it's IStateManager implementation.
Note: The information above applies only to advanced developers extending the class. It does not pertain to Web applications.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.SaveViewState
member.summary: Preserves to viewstate any changes made to the UltraWebToolbar element since the page was posted back.
member.returns: An state management object used by ASP.NET.

remarks.p: Subclasses must call this base implementation of SaveViewState prior to taking their own actions to preserve state. The state management object returned by this implementation should be added to a Pair, along with any state management object specific to extensions added by the subclass. The subclass must also then override to receive the Pair object back from the ASP.NET framework prior to Page_Load, restore its own state, and pass the base class implementation's state management object to base.LoadViewState unaltered.
Note: The information above applies only to advanced developers extending the class. It does not pertain to Web applications.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.LoadViewState(System.Object)
member.summary: Rehydrates all simple and structured properties of the UltraWebToolbar element from viewstate.
member.param: A state management object provided by ASP.NET.

remarks.p: Subclasses must call this base implementation of LoadViewState before taking their own actions to restore state. The savedState object should be of the type Pair, containing both the subclass' extension properties and the state management object of the UltraWebToolbar base class. Pair has two properties for this purposes. Which property (First or Second) should be used for the subclass must be decided by the overriding method implementation, however the and LoadViewState overriding implementations must be consistent on this decision. Before restoring subclass state, pass the UltraWebToolbar's state management object to base.LoadViewState to restore its properties from the previous HTTP response.
Note: The information above applies only to advanced developers extending the class. It does not pertain to Web applications.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.Infragistics#WebUI#WebSchedule#UltraWebToolbar#IButtonFactory#Create
member.summary: Creates a toolbar button with default properties.
member.returns: A default toolbar button.

remarks.p: This method employs any registered by subclasses of UltraWebToolbar, otherwise it defaults to its own factory method. It is used internally to create button objects.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.Infragistics#WebUI#WebSchedule#UltraWebToolbar#IButtonFactory#Create(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a toolbar button with the specified Text property.
member.param: Text to associate with the newly created button.
member.returns: A default toolbar button with Text set to text.

remarks.p: This method employs any registered by subclasses of UltraWebToolbar, otherwise it defaults to its own factory method. It is used internally to create button objects.
The appearance of text associated with a button depends on the type of button, please see the documentation of the respective button implementation class for more information.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.Movable
member.summary: Allows the UltraWebToolbar element to be dynamically repositionable by the end user, in up-level browsers only.

remarks.p: There are minor differences in how the UltraWebToolbar element moves on Internet Explorer and Netscape browsers. Internet Explorer allows the end user to drag the UltraWebToolbar smoothly across the surface of the web page. Netscape handles movement differently, and the end user must click on the (drag handle) to put down the UltraWebToolbar when they have finished dragging it.

Movement is confined within the dimensions of a <FRAME> element, however browsers may allow the UltraWebToolbar to move off of the edges of the client area. In these cases, scrollbars will frequently appear to allow the client area to accomodate the length of the UltraWebToolbar element.

If the UltraWebToolbar element appears to "snap-back" in its position across postbacks, check whether the <igtbar:UltraWebToolbar> element in the .ASPX document has a STYLE attribute. For repositioning to function properly, this STYLE attribute must not be removed.

The Movable property works with the and Width on the UltraWebToolbar instance to determine how wide the element is as the end user is repositioning it. If ItemWidthDefault and/or Width are not set to explicit values, then the UltraWebToolbar may appear to get longer/shorter as the end user moves it to the left and/or right. Developers must ensure that their applications have either set widths on a per-Toolbar item basis, or on the UltraWebToolbar element as a whole.
Repositioning of the UltraWebToolbar element is not supported by downlevel browsers.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.MergeStyles
member.summary: Determines whether Hover and Selected styles must automatically merge with the DefaultStyle of the UltraWebToolbar and Toolbar items.

remarks.p: When this property is set to true, the and styles will take on the values of the default style unless overridden for particular property values.
By default, this property is set to true so that style settings are blended automatically.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.RenderAnchors
member.summary: Determines whether a button's should be rendered as an HTML Anchor tag.

remarks.p: If the is not specified, the anchor will not be rendered. In a downlevel browser, anchors will always be rendered.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.ItemWidthDefault
member.summary: Determines the default width of items within the toolbar when not explicitly set within the item's default style. When this property is not set and the Item.Style.Width is also not set, the widths of items are automatically determined by the browser to occupy the horizontal width of the toolbar equally for each item. To set the widths of individual items, use the DefaultStyle.Width property setting.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.ItemPadding
member.summary: Determines the amount of interior cell padding used for the HTML <table> cells containing the WebToolbar's items.

remarks.p: The cellpadding attribute will no longer be rendered on the <table> tag if it has it's default value (0px) and Application Styling has been enabled. You should apply equivalent CSS styling to set the padding instead.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.ItemSpacing
member.summary: Determines the amount of spacing between the HTML <table> cells that contain the WebToolbar's items.

remarks.p: The cellspacing attribute will no longer be rendered on the <table> tag if it has it's default value (1px) and Application Styling has been enabled. You should apply equivalent CSS styling to set the border-spacing instead.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.TextAlign
member.summary: Determines the alignment of the items within the toolbar. Values for this property include Left, Right, Center and Justified.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.BackgroundImage
member.summary: An image Url that specifies an image to be displayed on the background of the toolbar. This image will appear wherever there is space not occupied by other toolbar items.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.Enabled
member.summary: Indicates whether the UltraWebToolbar is enabled or disabled.

remarks.p: A disabled UltraWebToolbar attempts to ignore client-side interactivity. Making the buttons of an UltraWebToolbar that has been disabled appear grayed out is done by developers specifying the DisabledImage on any instances, and changing the items' DefaultStyle to one more representative of a "disabled" appearance. Other toolbar items will have their text grayed-out, if supported by the end user's browser. Some browsers may not support graying-out of text, which is done through modern HTML Recommendation attributes.

While the UltraWebToolbar is disabled, developers should not change the Enabled state of any contained controls or toolbar items or add/remove items. Disabling the UltraWebToolbar will preserve a snapshot of the enabled state of existing items, that will be restored when the UltraWebToolbar is re-enabled. The behavior of manipulating the Items collection, or enabling items while UltraWebToolbar is disabled, is undefined.

Observe that when the control is operating with EnableViewState turned off, it becomes the responsibility of the developer to preserve and restore a snapshot of items' enabled states in whatsoever means best suits their web application.
remarks.seealso: Why enabling TBarButton while UltraWebToolbar is disabled fails?

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.OnTop
member.summary: Determines the Z-Index placement of the UltraWebToolbar.

remarks.p: When set to true, the UltraWebToolbar will always be rendered as the topmost object. This is especially useful when is set to true, so that the user always see the entire toolbar.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.CausesValidation
member.summary: Determines whether the UltraWebToolbar causes ASP.NET page validation to occur on the client-side before a postback.
member.value: True when client-side validation is triggered by a postback, or False when client-side validation is being suppressed.

remarks.p: By default, client-side page validation is performed when an UltraWebToolbar is about to post back. Therefore the default setting for the CausesValidation property is True.

member.summary: Sets which type of browser the html should be rendered for. Possible values are: Auto (Default), UpLevel, DownLevel.

summary.p: The image which when clicked on, will allow the UltraWebTool bar to be repositioned.

remarks.p: If this is not set, a vertical bar will be drawn by default.
Note: The image is only rendered if is set to True.

summary.p: The default style used for any item in the UltraWebToolbar.

remarks.p: This style is overridden by the item's DefaultStyle.

summary.p: The style to be applied to a TBarButton item when moused over.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.SelectedStyle
member.summary: Style applied on any selected item in the UltraWebToolbar upon selection.

remarks.p: By default, the only object which supports selection is the .

summary.p: A relative path to the JavaScript file.

remarks.p: The default JavaScript file is ig_webtoolbar.js. By default, this file is located in a virtual directory called /webtoolbar2.
Note: The JavaScript file is required for the UltraWebToolbar to function properly at runtime.

summary.p: A relative path to the Infragistics common JavaScript file.

remarks.p: The default common JavaScript file is ig_csom.js and is located in a virtual directory called /ig_common/scripts.
Note: The common JavaScript file is required for the UltraWebToolbar to function properly at runtime.

summary.p: A directory where images can be found.

remarks.p: When this property is set, any image specified for an UltraWebToolbar item, will be relative to this directory.
To specify an image in the current application directory, use a ./ prefix for the image name as in: ./myimage.gif

Developers must always use forward slashes ('/') in the path specification of this property. Use of the virgule ('\') in this property may cause a broken image link when the end user interacts with some UltraWebToolbar items.

summary.p: The collection of items for this UltraWebToolbar. The Items collections can be made up of different object types depending on requirements. The most common type is the TBarButton. Other types include: TBButtonGroup, TBLabel, TBSeparator, TBTextBox and TBCustom. All types, with the exception of TBCustom, derive from a common base type: TBObject. The TBCustom type derives from System.Web.UI.Control in order to support child controls.

remarks.p: This collection is created when the UltraWebToolbar is created.
This property is read-only.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.IsOverriden
member.summary: This property supports the Infragistics control infrastructure, and is not intended for use by applications.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.ClientSideEvents
member.summary: Structured record representing the names of Javascript event handlers for a variety of the UltraWebToolbar's client-side events.

remarks.p: Client-side events are events that occur in the Web browser, such as mouse-related events. Because the events are local to the browser, they must be implemented in Javascript. Client-side events do not require a new connection to the server, or a refresh of the current page. The other type of events found in the UltraWebToolbar are server-side events, which require the browser to make a new connection with the server in response to some event that occurs at the control level on the server, such as selection of a new group button.
When developers implement client-side events in their application, their Javascript routines should use the function names provided by the client-side event's corresponding ClientSideEvents property.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.Section508Compliant
member.summary: Indicates whether Section 508-compliant HTML should be generated.

remarks.p: Section 508-compliance provides support for assistive technologies that make HTML pages more accessible for end users that require it. It is named after the U.S. governmental legislation directed towards improving the accessibility of IT applications for the disabled.

The enhancements affected when Section508Compliant is True appear in the rendered HTML as ALT and TITLE tags targeting screen readers, and improved focus handling targeting screen magnifiers, to assist visually-impaired users in accessing a web applications. Additionally, TabIndex and AccessKey properties permit improved keyboard access to Toolbar items in applications where the a mouse cannot be used.

Setting the Section508Compliant alone does not ensure a web application is accessible, but maximizes the accessibility features afforded to an application from the UltraWebToolbar elements presented to users. It is a part of developers overall accessibility strategy when designing their web applications.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.TabIndex
member.summary: Tab index of the UltraWebToolbar element.

remarks.p: When the TabIndex is set on the UltraWebToolbar element, it percolates down to individual Toolbar items and serves as the "base" tab index.

As the "base" tab index, setting this property to a non-negative value causes it to be added to all individual Toolbar item's tab order attribute when they are rendered. For instance, if a developer sets this TabIndex to 100, and they have three buttons with individual TabIndex settings of 1, 2, and 3, then at render-time the Toolbar's items will have tab orders of 101, 102, and 103. This property can be used to quickly move all toolbar items ahead of, or behind, other web form elements in the tab order with one setting.

Developers should still set the TabIndex on individual items to customize the order in which they are tabbed to when the end user presses the TAB key. Tab order by default will be from left-to-right as the Toolbar items are rendered in document order.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.AccessKey
member.summary: Access Key of the UltraWebToolbar element (ignored).

remarks.p: This property is overriden from the base class, WebControl, in order to ignore all assignments to this property for the UltraWebToolbar element.

Developers should not set an AccessKey for the UltraWebToolbar element in their applications; instead, it is advisable an AccessKey be set on individual Toolbar items that must be keyboard-accessible.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.DocumentType

member.value: An enumerated value identifying recognized DTD types by their formal public identifier (FPI).

remarks.p: The value of this property will be undefined before the start of rendering.

member.summary: Assigns a user-defined implementation that is employed when instantiating new buttons.
member.value: A custom implementation of .

remarks.p: Applications developed with subclasses of should provide a plug-in implementation of that UltraWebToolbar can use to create objects of the appropriate type following postback. Customarily, the implementation of your will return the -cast result of your button subclass' constructor.
If subclassed TBarButton objects are added to the UltraWebToolbar, then every object must be of the same subclass. The IButtonFactory mechanism does not support multivariate subclassed buttons.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.EnableAppStyling
member.summary: Enables support on the UltraWebToolbar for the Application Styling Framework(tm).
member.value: True indicates Application Styling is enabled, False indicates Application Styling is disabled, and NotSet indicates support for Application Styling should default to page- or application-level settings.

remarks.p: Turn on support for Application Styling of this control when using the Application Styling Framework(tm) (ASF) by setting the EnableAppStyling property to True.

When EnableAppStyling has it's default value of NotSet, this control will defer the determination of whether to use Application Styling to settings you make at the page- or application-level. Place the WebPageStyler control on the same Web form as this control to configure ASF support for all controls on that Page. ASF support can also be turned on application-wide with the enableAppStyling attribute in your "web.config" file.
Turn off support for the ASF in this control (even though it may have been enabled at a higher level) by setting the EnableAppStyling property to False.
The default value for the EnableAppStyling property is NotSet for backward compatibility.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.StyleSetName
member.summary: Name of the Application Styling Framework(tm) style set defining the themed appearance for this control.

value.p: The name of the Application Styling Framework(tm) (ASF) style set which has been designed to give this control a consistent appearance with other controls in your application.
This property may return the empty string ("") to imply that the default style set (named "Default") should be used.

remarks.p: Web sites can configure a single, consistent, application-wide style set through the styleSetName attribute in their "web.config" file. Alternately, they can define the style set to apply Application Styling to all controls on a Page by placing a WebPageStyler control on that Page and setting it's StyleSetName property.
At the control level this property allows an application developer to customize the style set applied to a single instance of a control.

Normally, graphics designers will furnish you with a style set containing one or more style sheet files (one for each type of control) and image files. The name of the style set (with the exception of the "Default" style set) must appear in each Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) class name defined by this control's style sheet file.

The style set name appears within two places in your deployed Web site. First, the style set name appears as the ending of folder names which contain that style set's associated CSS style sheets and images. Second, the style set name appears within the CSS classes defined by those CSS style sheets. For example, in the "Onyx" style set would appear CSS classes named according to the convention, "igtb_OnyxButton."
When setting the StyleSetName property to empty string, the "Default" style set will be applied by application styling, if enabled.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.StyleSetPath
member.summary: Path containing the Application Styling Framework(tm) style set files for this type of control.

remarks.p: Web sites can configure the directory path containing their style set files application-wide by using the styleSetPath attribute of their "web.config" file. It is also possible to configure the style set path applicable to all controls on a Page that are subject to Application Styling by placing a WebPageStyler control on that Page and setting it's StyleSetPath property.
At the control level this property allows an application developer to customize the location of the style set being applied to a single instance of a control.

Be aware that customizing the style set path at the control level will not allow you to copy a style set's files to this new location, changing a few style property values in them, and then use it successfully with separate instances of the control referencing the original style set of the same name. This is because there would be naming collisions in the Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) class names, which will produce an undefined appearance. You must ensure the CSS class names defined by style sheets in the new style set path are unique from those CSS class names being used by other style sheets that may continue to be referenced. The recommended guidance in this scenario is to create a new style set having a new style set name, that contains your modifications.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.UltraWebToolbar.UltraWebToolbar.Infragistics#WebUI#Shared#IProvideStyleSheet#ParsedStyles
member.summary: Contains the ParsedStyleCollection consisting of CSS class definitions read from external sources.
member.value: The ParsedStyleCollection after external CSS class definitions have been parsed, or null (Nothing in Visual Basic .NET) if parsing hasn't been performed yet.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebWeekView.OnRaisePostBackEvent(System.String)
member.summary: Triggers server-side events and behaviors on the WebWeekView element.
member.param: Command information passed from the call the client-side script makes through fireServerEvent. This text has no relationship to the similarly-named System.EventArgs class.

remarks.p: This method gets invoked by the framework and is responsible for handling server-side events. Inheritors should not override this method to intercept server-side events before they are handled by the base class. Undefined behavior may result from interference in the event processing of the framework.
Consequently, developers that want to receive notification of an event should subscribe an event handler to the server-side events formally exposed by WebWeekView.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebWeekView.OnPreRender(System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Performs pre-render processing.
member.param: Event arguments passed-in by the ASP.NET Framework during the PreRender stage of the page lifecycle.

remarks.p: Inheritors overriding this method must call the base class implementation. Failure to call the base implementation can lead to Javascript errors resulting from omitting <include> blocks, a loss of styling from the element, and other undesirable behavior.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebWeekView.RenderContents(System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter)
member.summary: Renders contents to the supplied HtmlTextWriter.
member.param: An HtmlTextWriter sink to which output is being directed.

remarks.p: The contents associated with the WebMonthView and rendered by this method include fields to hold postback data from the client, and initialization Javascript to start-up the WebMonthView's client-side object model (CSOM) following the HTML markup comprising the element. RenderContents delegates responsibility for rendering HTML markup to the associated SmartRenderer created by .
Inheritors overriding this method must remember to call the base class implementation of the method before conducting most additional processing.

Post-processing of the rendered content can be accomplished if inheritors intercept what gets written to writer. This involves passing their own HtmlTextWriter wrapping some sort of buffered output sink, for example a StringWriter. When intercepting rendered content in this manner, it becomes the responsibility of the overriding method to ensure necessary content gets forwarded to the original HtmlTextWriter supplied by ASP.NET.

member.name: M:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebWeekView.GetResourceCss(System.String)
member.summary:
Get embedded css. If the control supports embedded StyleSheets, then it should override this method.
If cssStyleSheetName represents embedded css, then the control should return the value of the first param in the WebResourceAttribute with which that CSS-file was linked to. If the control supports multiple embedded css, then besides the empty-string it also should process other values of cssStyleSheetName param. For multiple CSSes the logic may assume syntax: "[nameOfFileOrPreset]", where "[" is a flag for embedded resources and "nameOfFileOrPreset" is a short name of the embedded file of a flag for a particular preset. It also should validate for an explicit path like "Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.CSS.Default.ig_webdayview.css".
member.param: The value of this.StyleSheetFileName property.
member.returns: Control must return null if cssStyleSheetName is not an embedded resource.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebWeekView.AppointmentFormatString
member.summary: The format string used to build text for an appointment.

remarks.p:
Notes: That property may include literal characters and replacement-string flags which are defined as "FormatTag_Xxxx" constants in WebScheduleInfo class.
Literal part of format is used as it is and passed directly to html.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebWeekView.AppointmentTooltipFormatString
member.summary: The format string used to build text for a tooltip of an appointment.

remarks.p: Notes: That property may include literal characters and replacement-string flags which are defined as "FormatTag_Xxxx" constants in WebScheduleInfo class. Literal part of format is passed directly to the "title" attribute of html-element with exception of " " flag which is replaced by the new-line character.

member.name: P:Infragistics.WebUI.WebSchedule.WebWeekViewClientEvents.NavigateNext
member.summary: Event fired when navigation button on the right side of the contol was clicked.

remarks.p:
Event handler on the client JavaScript may contain 3 parameters.
1st parameter contains reference to the WebWeekView object
2nd parameter contains reference to the ig_EventObject object
3rd parameter is number of weeks to navigate from current active date
This event can be canceled by "oEvent.cancel = true;".
